conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the Ampere force received by the \(\nu\)-shaped current-carrying wire, we need to follow these steps:
The wire forms a \(\nu\) shape with an included angle of \(60^\circ\). Each side of the \(\nu\) shape has a length of \(l\).

premise: The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the wire.
conclusion: Only the segments that are parallel to the magnetic field will experience a force.

premise: Both sides of the \(\nu\) shape are parallel to the magnetic field.
conclusion: Each side of the \(\nu\) shape contributes to the force.

premise: Each side of the \(\nu\) shape is \(l\).
conclusion: The total length of the wire contributing to the force is \(2l\).
The magnetic force \(F\) on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by: \(F = I \cdot B \cdot L \cdot \sin(\theta)\).
The force on each segment is \(F_{\text{segment}} = I \cdot B \cdot l \cdot 1 = I \cdot B \cdot l\).

premise: There are two segments, each with force \(I \cdot B \cdot l\).
conclusion: The total force is \(F_{\text{total}} = 2 \cdot (I \cdot B \cdot l) = 2I \cdot B \cdot l\).

premise: The total force calculated is \(2I \cdot B \cdot l\).
conclusion: The magnitude of the Ampere force received by the \(\nu\)-shaped current-carrying wire is \(\boxed{2IBl}\).
